\#\#\# User: When we consider the electron orbitals each orbital can have a single electron or an electron pair each with opposite spin.

Are all electrons always in pairs except the final single one if odd number electrons are considered

Is there a binding force due to the opposite spin and magnetic moments of this electron pair? If so what is its magnitude and is it significant compared to electric field effects?

Can individual electrons from a pair be excited to a higher energy level or are they both excited together?

Is it easier to excite a single solitary electron from an orbital than one from a pair?

Does the spin of the exciting photon impact which electron is excited?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Let's take these separately

> Are all electrons always in pairs except the final single one if odd number electrons are considered?

For a ground state atom, then this depends on the sort of shell you're looking at. If you have an odd number of electrons, the simplest sort of ground state will look like this.

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/iPG4F.png)

In this case, if you have unpaired electrons other than the final one, like, say,

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/E1ntD.png)

then you have essentially promoted a core electron to a valence or higher shell, and the atom is in an excited state. This is perfectly all right but the state is unstable and it will eventually decay radiatively to the ground state.

Things get more complicated, however, if you have half\-full shells at the same energy. In this case, you can have multiple unpaired electrons in different orbitals of the same shell, as long as those orbitals are degenerate in energy.

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/BIC5p.png)

The apparatus to decide which configurations will have lower energies are known as [Hund's rules](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hund%27s_rules). In general, you can and do get unpaired electrons in both even\- and odd\-$Z$ atoms. For examples, have a wander [here](http://www.webelements.com/atoms.html).

> Is there a binding force due to the opposite spin and magnetic moments of this electron pair? If so what is its magnitude and is it significant compared to electric field effects?

If electrons are in different shells, then the differences in their interaction with the core will dominate, and you get the first situation I described. If they are sitting inside a degenerate shell, then there are multiple interactions between them which compete with each other:

* The electrostatic interaction between them depends on how far apart they are. In general, if a configuration is spatially antisymmetric in exchange then the electrons will be further apart than in symmetric configurations.
* The symmetry of the wavefunction also affects how effectively the electrons can screen the nuclear charge for each other.
* Each electron also has a spin\-orbit coupling, which depends on both its orbital and its spin angular momentum. This is obviously affected by how one apportions spin and orbital angular momentum in a configuration.
* There are also magnetic interactions between the electrons, which depend both on the relative directions of the spins and on their average relative distance.

In general, the running order is electrostatic \> spin\-orbit \> spin\-spin effects. The detailed calculation of what dominates is more involved but this is well described by Hund's rules. The Wikipedia article has a good explanation of the hierarchy of effects. 

> Can individual electrons from a pair be excited to a higher energy level or are they both excited together?

In general, a double excitation is much harder to do than a single excitation. Double excitations are generally unstable: it often takes more energy to excite a second electron than it does to remove the first excited electron; such states are known as auto\-ionizing states. (In fact, even single excitations can do this: exciting a core electron is generally harder than ionizing a valence electron, so a core\-excited atom will generally auto\-ionize. This is known as the Auger effect.)

> Is it easier to excite a single solitary electron from an orbital than one from a pair?

This is sort of tricky because it depends on which sort of pair you're considering. If you've got something easy like

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/iPG4F.png)

then in general it will be easier to take the single electron simply because all the paired ones are in lower orbitals. Things are again trickier in half\-full shells, so if you're trying to determine, for example, whether it's the red or the blue electron in something like

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/WL85W.png)

that will be ionized, then you need to do a careful calculation of the energies of all the possible final states to see which one will be easier to get to. With enough photon energy, however, you can promote any of the electrons in the diagram anywhere. (On the other hand, some transitions might be dipole\-forbidden so they'll be much harder, or might require multiple photons. Still, you can pretty much make any eigenstate you want.)

> Does the spin of the exciting photon impact which electron is excited?

Yes, but in general it depends on the situation. It's hard to say without having a more specific situation. The rules for what can and cannot happen with a given type of radiative transition are known as [selection rules](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selection_rule); in general they depend on the spin, orbital, and total angular momentum of the initial and final states, and on the multipolar order of the transition. In addition, two\- or more\-photon transitions are possible, further complicating the picture.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: An atom is in its ground state with a configuration similar to:
[Image of electron configuration with paired electrons in lower shells and a single unpaired electron in the highest occupied shell]

You want to excite this atom using a single photon. Which of the following statements is most accurate?

A) It's equally easy to excite any electron, regardless of whether it's paired or unpaired.
B) It's easiest to excite one electron from a pair in the lower shells due to their opposite spins.
C) It's easiest to excite the unpaired electron in the highest occupied shell.
D) It's easiest to excite both electrons in a pair simultaneously.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: In the ground state configuration described, it's generally easiest to excite the unpaired electron in the highest occupied shell. This is because:

1. The unpaired electron is in the highest energy level, requiring less energy to promote to the next available orbital.
2. Exciting electrons from fully occupied lower shells typically requires more energy.
3. Double excitations (exciting both electrons in a pair simultaneously) are much harder and generally unstable.
4. The spin of the electrons in pairs doesn't make them easier to excite; in fact, the Pauli exclusion principle contributes to their stability in the lower orbitals.

While specific selection rules can complicate matters depending on the exact transition, in general, the unpaired electron in the highest occupied shell is the most accessible for excitation.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An engineer is designing a device that uses a USB Type-C connector for both USB functionality and additional TTL signals. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the use of spare pins in the USB Type-C connector for TTL inputs and outputs?

A) It's impossible to use any pins in a USB Type-C connector for non-USB signals due to strict USB protocol requirements.

B) The spare pins can be used for TTL signals without any considerations, as they are completely isolated from USB functionality.

C) The spare pins can be used for TTL signals, but only if the PCB design ensures these pins are not connected to USB controllers on both ends, and careful consideration is given to pin selection to minimize crosstalk.

D) All 24 pins in a USB Type-C connector must be used for USB functionality, leaving no spare pins for additional signals.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The documentation clearly states that it is possible to use the remaining pins in a USB Type-C connector for TTL inputs and outputs, but with important caveats. The designer must ensure that the PCB layout doesn't connect these pins to USB controllers on both ends. Additionally, care must be taken in selecting which pins to use, considering the cable layout to minimize crosstalk, especially for high-frequency or high-amplitude signals. This approach allows for a simple and robust design using a single connector for multiple purposes, but requires careful engineering considerations.

Option A is incorrect because it is possible to use spare pins for non-USB signals. Option B oversimplifies the situation and ignores the necessary precautions. Option D is false, as not all 24 pins are required for USB functionality, leaving some available for other uses.

\#\#\# User: Let's suppose a theoretical case where a car doesn't start with rest but with a high velocity enough to kill a man. The car doesn't change it's velocity i.e no acceleration or deceleration and hits a man after a while(Assume car is moving on straight path). Since, velocity is constant, acceleration is zero. So is the force exerted by the car zero Newton? And If so will the man die?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A force is basically a pull or a push. A car that hits a person also pushes on him and so exerts a force.
If a car is moving at all then surely it has momentum. When it hits a man, it exerts force on the man which for an instant changes it's velocity and hence momentum. By Newton's third law, the man equally experiences an impulse/change in momentum while the car nudges him forward. The bottom line is: the car definitely exerts force on the man.
It is important however, to understand that zero acceleration doesn't mean zero momentum. Even though a car moving with uniform velocity doesn't experience any net force but that is not to say it doesn't have momentum. It will not be wise to say F\=ma and a\=0 so F\=0\. That equation applies not to the man but the car itself and will only hold up until the car hits the man. (since it was assumed the car was moving with zero acceleration). Once the car hits him, the equation becomes F∆t\=∆mv according to Newton's second law. Hope that one helps.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A car traveling at a constant velocity of 100 km/h on a straight road collides with a stationary pedestrian. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the physics of this collision?

A) The force exerted on the pedestrian is zero because the car's acceleration is zero.
B) The car's momentum remains constant throughout the collision.
C) The pedestrian experiences an impulse equal to the change in the car's momentum.
D) The collision can be fatal even though the car's acceleration was zero before impact.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation:
A) is incorrect because force is not solely dependent on acceleration. In a collision, force is exerted even if the car's acceleration was zero before impact.
B) is incorrect because during the collision, the car's momentum changes as it transfers some of its momentum to the pedestrian.
C) is incorrect because while the pedestrian does experience an impulse, it's equal to the pedestrian's change in momentum, not the car's.
D) is correct because a car moving at high velocity has significant momentum, which can cause severe or fatal injuries upon impact, regardless of its acceleration before the collision. The force exerted during the collision is what matters, not the car's prior acceleration.

\#\#\# Top Answer: I added aerial imagery from GIS server and created fishnet over the area of interest:
[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/sY0ke.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/sY0ke.jpg)

I use fishnet as index layer for my data driven pages, making sure the sorting order coincides with record order in fishnet table.

I applied script (see below) to travel through pages, export them to temp raster, clip it to PNG raster named after page name.
Result shows clipped tiles with source image faded:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/XpfFh.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/XpfFh.jpg)

Script has 1 input parameter – output folder to save your tiles. Before running it I suggest you to play with resolution (dpi) and cell size (to get best resolution possible) of fishnet.

```
# EXPORT SCREENs TO RASTERs
import arcpy, traceback, os, sys, time
from arcpy import env
env.overwriteOutput = True
outFolder=arcpy.GetParameterAsText(0)
dpi=1200
tempRaster=outFolder+os.sep+"victim.png"

## ERROR HANDLING
def showPyMessage():
    arcpy.AddMessage(str(time.ctime()) + " - " + message)

try:
    mxd = arcpy.mapping.MapDocument("CURRENT")
    ddp = mxd.dataDrivenPages
    thePagesLayer = arcpy.mapping.ListLayers(mxd,ddp.indexLayer.name)[0]
#   GET RECTANGLES
    g=arcpy.Geometry()
    geometryList=arcpy.CopyFeatures_management(thePagesLayer,g)
#   EXPORT PAGES
    df = arcpy.mapping.ListDataFrames(mxd)[0]
    fld = ddp.pageNameField.name
    Page_Names=arcpy.da.TableToNumPyArray(thePagesLayer, fld)
    for pageID in range(1, ddp.pageCount+1):
        ddp.currentPageID = pageID
        arcpy.RefreshActiveView()
        time.sleep(3)
        arcpy.mapping.ExportToPNG(mxd,tempRaster,df,dpi,world_file=True)
        fName=outFolder+os.sep+Page_Names[pageID-1][0]+".png"
        anExtent=geometryList[pageID-1].extent
        envelope='%f %f %f %f' %(anExtent.XMin, anExtent.YMin, anExtent.XMax, anExtent.YMax,)
#   CLIP EXPORTED BY PAGE RECTANGLE
        arcpy.Clip_management (tempRaster, envelope,fName)
        arcpy.AddMessage('%s processed' %fName)
except:
    message = "\n*** PYTHON ERRORS *** "; showPyMessage()
    message = "Python Traceback Info: " + traceback.format_tb(sys.exc_info()[2])[0]; showPyMessage()
    message = "Python Error Info: " +  str(sys.exc_type)+ ": " + str(sys.exc_value) + "\n"; showPyMessage()

```

Sorting order of pages is most important. Before 'travel' starts script creates a list of rectangles/pages and uses i\-th (page no \-1\) one to clip screenshot. If order of pages\<\>order of records in fishnet table, script will produce weird results if any.

Cancel script after few steps and check results. Restart if they make sense.

**UPDATE May 3, 2016**

It seems few people found script useful. I modified it, so that page order and field type to store page name don't matter anymore.

```
# EXPORTS SCREEN TO RASTER(s)
import arcpy, traceback, os, sys, time
from arcpy import env
env.overwriteOutput = True
outFolder=arcpy.GetParameterAsText(0)
env.workspace = outFolder
dpi=1200
tempRaster=outFolder+os.sep+"victim.png"
## ERROR HANDLING
def showPyMessage():
    arcpy.AddMessage(str(time.ctime()) + " - " + message)
try:
    mxd = arcpy.mapping.MapDocument("CURRENT")
    ddp = mxd.dataDrivenPages
#   GET PAGES INFO
    thePagesLayer = arcpy.mapping.ListLayers(mxd,ddp.indexLayer.name)[0]
    df = arcpy.mapping.ListDataFrames(mxd)[0]
    fld = ddp.pageNameField.name
    for pageID in range(1, ddp.pageCount+1):
        ddp.currentPageID = pageID
        arcpy.RefreshActiveView()
        time.sleep(3)
        arcpy.mapping.ExportToPNG(mxd,tempRaster,df,dpi,world_file=True)
        fName=outFolder+os.sep+str(ddp.pageRow.getValue(fld))+".png"
        rect=ddp.pageRow.getValue("Shape")
        anExtent=rect.extent
        envelope='%f %f %f %f' %(anExtent.XMin, anExtent.YMin, anExtent.XMax, anExtent.YMax,)
#   CLIP EXPORTED BY PAGE RECTANGLE
        arcpy.Clip_management (tempRaster, envelope,fName)
        arcpy.AddMessage('%s processed' %fName)
    arcpy.Delete_management(tempRaster)
except:
    message = "\n*** PYTHON ERRORS *** "; showPyMessage()
    message = "Python Traceback Info: " + traceback.format_tb(sys.exc_info()[2])[0]; showPyMessage()
    message = "Python Error Info: " +  str(sys.exc_type)+ ": " + str(sys.exc_value) + "\n"; showPyMessage()

```

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You have a raster dataset in Cache/Mixed format in ArcGIS and need to export it as a georeferenced image for use in QGIS. Which of the following approaches is most likely to successfully accomplish this task?

A) Use the "Export tile cache" tool in ArcGIS to convert the cache to a .tpk file, then import it directly into QGIS.

B) Use the "Export data" option in ArcGIS to save the raster as a new image file.

C) Create a fishnet grid over the area of interest, use data driven pages to export individual PNG tiles, then mosaic the tiles together.

D) Directly copy the _alllayers folder containing the cache tiles into the QGIS project folder.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because .tpk files are not directly supported by QGIS. 
Option B is incorrect because, as stated in the question, this results in a black image.
Option C is correct. This method, described in detail in the top answer, allows for exporting the cached data as georeferenced image tiles that can be mosaicked together.
Option D is incorrect because QGIS cannot directly read the ArcGIS cache format stored in the _alllayers folder.

The correct approach involves creating a fishnet grid, using data driven pages to export individual tiles as PNG images with world files, and then combining these georeferenced tiles. This method overcomes the limitations of directly exporting the cached data and provides a way to create a usable raster image for QGIS.

\#\#\# User: Hoodie has a hood, sweater is knitted or crocheted, pullover, jumper and sweatshirt seem to all be related but neither has a zipper, zip\-up does but at least in the pictures they all seem to have hoods too and jacket is for outdoors. What do you call a garment that is like a hoodie but has a zipper and doesn't have a hood?

And yes, I realize there are differences between different variants of English but if I wanted to reference them all, this would be a book (English seems to have a ridiculous number of names for garments that are all similar).

Also, is there a universal name for all/most of the above so I don't have to wonder about the details every time I want to mention one?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I'd call it a *cardigan*, or perhaps a *zip\-up cardigan* if I wanted to be specific.

From [The Free Dictionary](https://www.thefreedictionary.com/cardigan):

> **cardigan** n.  
> 
> A knitted garment, such as a sweater or jacket, that opens down the full length of the front.

If it's not actually knitted, then I'd go ahead and call it a *jacket*. (Note that knitted fabric still counts as knitted. Most t\-shirts and hoodies are made of knitted fabric.)

[Same source](https://www.thefreedictionary.com/jacket):

> **jacket** n.
> 
> 
> 1. A short coat usually extending to the hips.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A cardigan is the most accurate term for the described garment. The key features mentioned are:
1. Similar to a hoodie
2. Has a zipper
3. Doesn't have a hood

A cardigan is defined as "a knitted garment, such as a sweater or jacket, that opens down the full length of the front." This matches the description perfectly, as it can be similar to a hoodie in material and style, typically has a full-length zipper, and doesn't necessarily include a hood.

Sweatshirt (A) and pullover (B) are incorrect because they usually don't have zippers down the front.

Jacket (D) could be considered partially correct, especially if the garment isn't knitted. However, jackets are typically associated with outerwear, while the question implies an indoor garment similar to a hoodie. Therefore, cardigan is the more precise term in this context.

The question tests the student's ability to differentiate between various types of upper body garments and understand the specific characteristics that define each type.

\#\#\# User: I discovered empirically what to me is an amazing lemma
concerning face angles of a tetrahedron.
Let $\\triangle abc$ be a triangle in the $xy$\-plane, and $d$ the
apex of a tetrahedron with positive $z$ coordinate.
The lemma is this:

> **Lemma**. The locus of points $d$ for which the sum
>  of the nonbase tetrahedron face angles incident to $b$ sum to $\\pi$,
>  $$\\angle dba \+ \\angle dbc \= \\pi$$
>  is a vertical (parallel to $z$) *bisector plane* which meets the $xy$\-plane
>  in a line $L$ that has the property
>  that the angle of incidence $\\beta$ between $ab$ and $L$ is equal
>  to the angle of reflection $\\beta$ between $bc$ and $L$.

![TetraSumPi](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ezqsY.jpg)

If I express this relationship in terms of `ArcCos( )`'s of the relevant
angles, it all works out algebraically/trigonometrically. So I have a "proof" in this
(limited) sense.
But surely for such a simple *angle of incidence \= angle of reflection*
relationship there is a concise geometrical explanation—maybe involving reflecting light rays...?

Amidst a much longer proof, this was at one point a critical lemma, but now I have circumvented
its need (I think?!). Nevertheless, it would be illuminating to see a more revealing proof. Thanks for ideas and/or insights!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This is still in terms of trigonometry, but it's pretty quick. Let $\\vec{u}$ and $\\vec{v}$ be the unit vectors in the direction of $\\vec{bc}$ and $\\vec{ba}$, respectively. We have
$$\\angle dba \+ \\angle dbc \= \\pi \\iff \\cos(\\angle dba)\+\\cos(\\angle dbc)\=0\\iff \\vec{u}\\cdot \\vec{bd}\+\\vec{v}\\cdot\\vec{bd}\=0$$
$$\\iff (\\vec{u}\+\\vec{v})\\cdot \\vec{bd}\=0$$
But the line $\\vec{u}\+\\vec{v}$ is the internal angle bisector of $\\angle abc$ so this is precisely the plane orthogonal to that passing through $b$.

49.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Consider a tetrahedron ABCD where triangle ABC lies in the xy-plane and D is the apex with a positive z-coordinate. Which of the following statements correctly describes the locus of points D where the sum of the non-base face angles incident to B (∠DBA + ∠DBC) equals π?

A) It's a horizontal plane parallel to the xy-plane that intersects the z-axis at a specific height.

B) It's a vertical plane that bisects the angle ABC and meets the xy-plane in a line where the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection with respect to AB and BC.

C) It's a spherical surface centered at point B with a radius determined by the dimensions of triangle ABC.

D) It's a conical surface with its apex at B and its axis along the altitude of triangle ABC from vertex B.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. The locus of points D satisfying the condition forms a vertical plane (parallel to the z-axis) that bisects the angle ABC. This plane intersects the xy-plane in a line L, where the angle of incidence between AB and L equals the angle of reflection between BC and L. This can be proven using vector algebra, as shown in the documentation, where the condition (u⃗+v⃗)⋅b⃗d=0 implies that b⃗d is perpendicular to the internal angle bisector of ∠ABC.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Ask for feedback from the developers which were part of the team developing the product he 'owned'. You could ask questions like:

1. Was he able to answer requirements related questions in a timely manner?
2. When presented with multiple alternatives in regards to a feature, was he able to make a clear decision with regard of what he wants?
3. How often did he change the requirements? This is something that always happens. Being able to cope with this is what it means to be agile. However, if this happens very often, then that's a sign that the product owner has no idea of what he actually wants
4. Was he able to provide clear feedback during demo sessions?

Option A is incorrect because frequent requirement changes can indicate a lack of clear vision.

\#\#\# User: I am getting this error:

```
sudo apt-get install emacs23
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree       
Reading state information... Done
E: Unable to locate package emacs23

```

Moreover, I ran:

```
sudo apt-get upgrade
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree       
Reading state information... Done
0 upgraded, 0 newly installed, 0 to remove and 0 not upgraded.

```

I have the latest public release version 12\.10 Quantal Quetzal of Ubuntu.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You need to update your package lists.

Run:

```
sudo apt-get update

```

Then try again. That will fix everything.

You see, when Ubuntu software developers write their software, they send it to the Launchpad servers, where they compile and process the code. Once the code has been successfully compiled, the new package replaces the old package, and the package lists are updated to reflect that change.

Note that it's just the package lists on *their* server, not your computer. `sudo apt-get update` fetches the latest package info from the servers, at which point your computer processes it.  

The command `sudo apt-get upgrade` checks the package lists (the ones stored on your computer) and compares the software in the package list with the actual versions you have installed. If any of your software has a version newer than it listed in the package list, it will download and install it.

Running `sudo apt-get install <PACKAGE>` checks your package list for that software. If found, it downloads and installs it.  

(note that the package *lists* do not contain the software themselves \- only the name, version, and the URL to download the software.)

Anyway, I hope my little speech helped you understand Ubuntu's package system a little better!

Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A Ubuntu user is trying to install the 'emacs23' package but encounters an "Unable to locate package" error. After running 'sudo apt-get upgrade', they see that no packages are upgraded, installed, or removed. What is the most likely cause of this issue and the appropriate solution?

A) The package 'emacs23' is not available for their Ubuntu version. They should search for an alternative package.

B) The user's internet connection is faulty. They should check their network settings and try again.

C) The package lists on the user's local system are outdated. They should run 'sudo apt-get update' before attempting to install the package.

D) The 'emacs23' package has been deprecated. The user should manually download and compile the source code.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The most likely cause of this issue is that the package lists on the user's local system are outdated. When the user runs 'sudo apt-get install emacs23' and receives an "Unable to locate package" error, it suggests that the local package lists don't have information about this package. The fact that 'sudo apt-get upgrade' shows no changes further indicates that the local system is unaware of any updates.

The correct solution is to run 'sudo apt-get update'. This command fetches the latest package information from the Ubuntu servers, updating the local package lists. After running this command, the user's system will have the most current information about available packages, including 'emacs23' if it's available for their Ubuntu version. Once the package lists are updated, the user can then successfully run the install command for the desired package.

\#\#\# User: The close dialog no longer contains this option:

> Questions must demonstrate a minimal understanding of the problem being solved. Tell us what you've tried to do, why it didn't work, and how it should work.

This was probably the close reason I most commonly used after *not a real question* and *too localized* were removed.

Now consider this question: [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21052253/what\-is\-the\-output\-of\-the\-following\-c\-program](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21052253/what-is-the-output-of-the-following-c-program)

It presents a small 15 line program and asks what the output is. It has received a large number of downvotes. It will serve no purpose for future visitors. I see no reason for it to remain on the site. 

This has just been put on hold as *too broad*. This seems ridiculous to me. It's is not a broad question. It is a direct and exceptionally specific question. I posit that the voters picked too broad because they felt it should be closed, but could not find a good reason from the options available. But still picked one option even though it does not fit.

This presents a very bad picture to the asker. We are telling them the question is too broad but the exact opposite is the case.

What is the correct way for us to deal with a question of this nature. One that in days gone by would have been closed as *too localized*. Should we:

1. Close it. And if so, using which reason.
2. Leave it open and answer it.

**Update**

My question here concerns just the question that was asked. I note that the question was closed before clarifying comments were added by the asker.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It *probably* is too broad. But that's really a secondary problem.

As\-asked, the answer to the question is 8\. That's easy for anyone to determine, and also too short to even be posted on Stack Overflow. You have to assume that the asker either wants something else (but didn't state it) or is trolling. So, Unclear. 

[As Robert noted](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/215702/should-a-very-localized-question-be-closed-and-if-so-how/215703#215703), the asker wants someone to run the program on paper for him. Asking someone to sit down and walk you through a specific assignment when you have *no* idea what (if anything) they know is akin to requesting an introductory programming tutorial. "How do I run a program on paper?" might've been a useful question though.

To answer the question you asked in the title, "very localized" is a hard call to make when invalidating a question: Stack Overflow has an *insanely* broad audience, and it never ceases to amaze me how many obscure or code\-specific questions are found useful by others. I try to avoid predicting whether or not *most* questions will be found useful by others anymore... That said, there are a class of questions that we've repeatedly found to be a waste of space: those that were solved by a simple typographical fix or were solved by changes outside the scope of the question itself ("I rebooted and the problem went away"). There's a new off\-topic reason for these.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: What is the most appropriate action to take for a very specific programming question on Stack Overflow that shows no research effort and is unlikely to help future visitors?

A) Close it as "Too Broad"
B) Close it as "Unclear what you're asking"
C) Leave it open and answer it
D) Close it as "Off-topic" due to lack of debugging details

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct approach is to close such a question as "Unclear what you're asking." While the question may seem very specific, it likely lacks context or clarity about what the asker truly wants to know. As mentioned in the documentation, for questions like the C program output example, the literal answer might be too simple to post on Stack Overflow. This suggests the asker either wants something else they haven't clearly stated or may be trolling.

Option A is incorrect because a very specific question is not truly "too broad," even if some users might choose this option out of a lack of better choices.

Option C is inappropriate because answering such questions encourages low-quality posts and doesn't help improve the overall quality of the site.

Option D, while potentially applicable in some cases, is not the best choice here. The question isn't necessarily about debugging, but rather about understanding or clarity.

Closing as "Unclear what you're asking" prompts the asker to provide more context, explain their thought process, or clarify what specific aspect of the problem they need help with, which is the most constructive approach for improving the question quality.

The maximum rotational speed should be defined so that applying maximum torque will stop the rotation of the object within one rotation. If I know my torque and moment of inertia, how can I find the maximum rotational velocity to allow me to stop the object in one rotation?

Time is whatever is needed.

I've tried finding the angular acceleration required to stop the object, but that leaves me with the time variable. Of the equations I've tried, I'm left with a time variable as well as the maximum angular velocity.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Hint: Velocities include directions. Light can travel in different directions. So...

55.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: An object with a moment of inertia I is rotating with an angular velocity ω. A constant torque τ is applied in the opposite direction to stop the rotation. If the object comes to a complete stop after exactly one full rotation, what is the relationship between the initial angular velocity ω, the applied torque τ, and the moment of inertia I?

A) ω² = 4πτ/I
B) ω² = 2πτ/I
C) ω² = πτ/I
D) ω² = 8πτ/I

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
To solve this problem, we need to use the work-energy theorem for rotational motion. The work done by the torque to stop the rotation is equal to the change in rotational kinetic energy.

Work done = τθ, where θ is the angular displacement (2π for one full rotation)
Change in rotational kinetic energy = ½I(0² - ω²) = -½Iω²

Equating these:
τ(2π) = ½Iω²

Rearranging:
ω² = 4πτ/I

Therefore, the correct answer is B) ω² = 2πτ/I.

Option A is incorrect as it's twice the correct value. Option C is half the correct value, and option D is four times the correct value. The relationship ω² = 2πτ/I provides the exact condition for the object to stop after one full rotation when the given torque is applied.

I used the picasa photos implimentation

\#\#\# Top Answer: It turned out Picasa has an extra privacy parameter on location data of photos that are going to be shared as public.

The "Show photo locations to viewers of this album" parameter must be checked for geotags to be sent with the photos metadata, even if those photos are already publicly shared.

See also OP's answer below.

---

Unfortunately it looks like your photos miss geographic coordinates data (no geotag).

In Picasaweb, open your photo and then click on the "full details page" link on the far right menu (for left\-to\-right languages). There should be `Latitude` and `Longitude` data. Like for example in photos from Bjørn's album (author of Leaflet.photo plugin): [https://picasaweb.google.com/lh/photo/nfgH9Rj2jbZlllxLLM0aDNMTjNZETYmyPJy0liipFm0?full\-exif\=true](https://picasaweb.google.com/lh/photo/nfgH9Rj2jbZlllxLLM0aDNMTjNZETYmyPJy0liipFm0?full-exif=true)

You can also inspect the JSONP response by simply typing your URL (`https://picasaweb.google.com/data/feed/api/user/MY-USER-ID/albumid/MY-ALBUM-ID?alt=json-in-script`) in the browser location bar: you need `['georss$where']['gml$Point']['gml$pos']['$t']` attributes available for the plugin to be able to determine the location of your photos.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A developer is trying to display geotagged photos from a Picasa album on a Leaflet map using the Leaflet.photo plugin. The implementation fails despite the album being public and the JSON data being accessible. What is the most likely reason for this failure?

A) The Leaflet.photo plugin is incompatible with Picasa's API
B) The JSON data format from Picasa is incorrect
C) The "Show photo locations to viewers of this album" setting is unchecked in Picasa
D) The developer forgot to include the Leaflet.photo plugin in their project

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The most likely reason for the failure is that the "Show photo locations to viewers of this album" setting is unchecked in Picasa. As mentioned in the documentation, Picasa has an extra privacy parameter for location data of photos that are going to be shared publicly. Even if the photos are publicly shared, this specific setting must be checked for geotags to be sent with the photos' metadata. Without this setting enabled, the geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) would be missing from the photo data, preventing the Leaflet.photo plugin from correctly placing the photos on the map. The other options are less likely: the plugin is designed to work with Picasa, the JSON format is typically correct if the album link works, and the question implies that the developer attempted to use the plugin, suggesting it was included in the project.

58.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following Terminal commands would correctly list the IP addresses of connected VPN clients on a macOS 10.8 server, given that the method described in the 10.6 Server manual no longer works?

A) netstat -an | grep "ESTABLISHED" | awk '{print $5}'
B) ps -ef | awk '/[p]ppd/ {print substr($NF,2);}'
C) ifconfig | grep "inet " | awk '{print $2}'
D) lsof -i | grep "ESTABLISHED" | awk '{print $9}'

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
The correct answer is B: ps -ef | awk '/[p]ppd/ {print substr($NF,2);}'

This command specifically targets the pppd (Point-to-Point Protocol Daemon) processes, which are typically used for VPN connections. It uses 'ps' to list all processes, 'awk' to filter for pppd processes, and then extracts the IP address from the last field of the output.

Option A would list all established network connections, not just VPN clients.
Option C would list all network interface IP addresses, including non-VPN connections.
Option D would list all established network connections using lsof, but again, not specific to VPN clients.

The question tests understanding of command-line tools, process management, and VPN connection handling in macOS, as well as the ability to interpret and adapt information from outdated documentation to current systems.

\#\#\# User: I have this image that is for the amp I am using which allows you to add a headphone jack to it:
[![](https://i.stack.imgur.com/CorIt.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/CorIt.png)

I have already hooked up the regular speakers and power to the amp, now I just want to add a headphone jack. It says to wire the grounds from both speakers together, then to the jack, and to wire the left and right audio points to it directly. Can someone explain what the "wire to internal speaker" points mean? I know it sounds simple, but for instance what are the arrows for? They look like diode symbols to me (I thought this because they could have easily done without the arrows).

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This kind of jack allows left and right speakers to be connected when no headphone plug is inserted (top image).  

Upon inserting a headphone plug, both speakers are disconnected by mechanical force of the plug forcing both switch contacts to open. Output current is directed only to headphones, allowing private listening to the headphones only (bottom image).   

[![stereo jack with internal headphone/speaker switch](https://i.stack.imgur.com/jJPCE.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/jJPCE.png)

59.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A stereo amplifier circuit needs to be modified to include a headphone jack with automatic speaker cut-off functionality. Which of the following statements correctly describes the wiring and operation of this modification?

A) The ground wires from both speakers should be connected directly to the amplifier's ground, bypassing the headphone jack entirely.

B) When a headphone plug is inserted, the mechanical force closes switch contacts, redirecting audio to both headphones and speakers simultaneously.

C) The arrows in the diagram represent diodes that must be added to the circuit to protect against reverse current flow when switching between speakers and headphones.

D) The headphone jack contains internal switches that open when a plug is inserted, disconnecting the speakers and routing audio solely to the headphones.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. The diagram and explanation show that the headphone jack contains built-in switches. When no headphone is plugged in, these switches allow the audio signal to pass through to the speakers. However, when a headphone plug is inserted, it mechanically forces these switches open, cutting off the connection to the speakers and routing the audio solely to the headphones. This allows for automatic switching between speaker and headphone output without additional circuitry. The arrows in the diagram do not represent diodes, but rather indicate the mechanical action of the plug opening the switches. Options A, B, and C all contain inaccuracies about the wiring or operation of this type of headphone jack.
